member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigComplex.Sqrt(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigComplex)
member.summary: Calculate the square root of a BigComplex number. The second root can be found by the conjugate of the result. You can use this method to get the square root of a negative value (including a BigNumbers value). e.g. BigComplex z = BigComplex.Sqrt(-5);
member.returns: The positive square root as a BigComplex number.

member.returns: A list with up to 2 complex numbers, which are the roots.

Contains everything relating to constants.
Power, root, exponential, and logarithm methods for BigNumbers.
Old, cut code, keeping just in case.
Trigonometric methods for BigNumbers.

member.summary: The part of a number in scientific notation or in floating-point representation, consisting of its significant digits.

member.summary: The power of 10.

member.name: P:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Sign
member.summary: The sign of the value. The same convention is used as for BigInteger. -1 means negative 0 means zero 1 means positive

member.name: P:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.NumSigFigs
member.summary: Get the number of significant figures.

member.name: P:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.MaxSigFigs
member.summary: This property determines the maximum number of significant figures to keep in a BigNumbers value. After any calculation, the result will be rounded to this many significant figures. This not only helps control memory usage by controlling the size of the significand, but also determines when to halt numerical methods, e.g. for calculating a square root or logarithm. If this property is modified, only new objects and calculations are affected by it. If you want to reduce the number of significant figures in an existing value, use RoundSigFigs().

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.op_Implicit(System.Half)~Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal
member.summary: Implicit cast from Half to BigNumbers. NB: The resulting BigNumbers value is exactly the value encoded by the Half. However, since Halves only approximate decimal values, it's possible that only the first few digits are valid in terms of the intended value. Therefore, you may need to use RoundSigFigs() to get the value you really want.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.op_Implicit(System.Single)~Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal
member.summary:
Implicit cast from float to BigNumbers. NB: The resulting BigNumbers value is exactly the value encoded by the float. However, since floats only approximate decimal values, it's possible that only the first 6-9 digits are valid in terms of the intended value. Therefore, you may need to use RoundSigFigs() to get the value you really want, e.g.
BigNumbers bd = BigNumbers.RoundSigFigs(1.2345f, FloatMaxSigFigs);

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.op_Implicit(System.Double)~Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal
member.summary:
Implicit cast from double to BigNumbers. NB: The resulting BigNumbers value is exactly the value encoded by the double. However, since doubles only approximate decimal values, it's possible that only the first 15-17 digits are valid in terms of the intended value. Therefore, you may need to use RoundSigFigs() to get the value you really want, e.g.
BigNumbers bd = BigNumbers.RoundSigFigs(1.2345, DoubleMaxSigFigs);

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.op_Implicit(System.Decimal)~Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal
member.summary: Implicit cast from decimal to BigNumbers. The cast is implicit because any decimal value can be cast to a BigNumbers exactly, without loss of information. However, rounding off using Round() or RoundSigFigs() can cause information loss. We don't need to use Parse() or division operations here, because the base is decimal. We can just extract the parts of the decimal from the bits and construct a BigNumbers from those. This method should be faster than using ToString() and Parse().

member.summary: Convert a BigNumbers to a standard binary floating point type. If the BigNumbers is outside the range for this type, this method will return negative or positive infinity as needed, without throwing an exception.
member.typeparam: The standard binary floating point type.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Pow(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: Calculate the value of x^y where x and y are both BigNumbers values.
member.returns: The result of the calculation, rounded off to the current value of MaxSigFigs.
member.exception: If there is no real result or a real result cannot otherwise be computed.

member.summary: Calculate the square of a number.

member.summary: Calculate the cube of a number.

member.summary: Calculate the square root of a real number.
member.returns: The square root of the number.
member.exception: If the argument is negative.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Cbrt(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: Calculate the cube root of a real number.
member.returns: The cube root of the number.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Hypot(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: Calculate the length of the hypotenuse of a right triangle.
member.param: The length of one of the short sides of the triangle.
The length of the other short side of the triangle.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.FirstComplexRoot(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the first root of a complex number, defined by real and imaginary parts.
member.param: The real part of the complex value.
The imaginary part of the complex value.
The degree of the roots to be computed.
member.returns: A tuple representing the first root.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.ComplexRoots(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,System.Int32)
member.summary: Determine all n roots of the complex number defined by real and imaginary parts. This will include complex conjugates. This method is really just for internal use by BigNumbers and BigComplex, but because they are different projects and packages, I have to make it public. I couldn't place it in BigComplex as I want to avoid a circular dependency. Ordinary users of the class should use BigComplex.Roots(), which calls this.
member.param: The real part of the complex value.
The imaginary part of the complex value.
The degree of the roots to be computed.
member.returns: An array of tuples representing complex numbers.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.ComplexExp(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: Computes e raised to a given complex power.
member.param: The real part of the complex exponent.
The imaginary part of the complex exponent.
member.returns: The complex result as a tuple of 2 BigNumbers values.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.ComplexLog(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: Natural logarithm of a complex number.
member.remarks: This method finds the principal value only.
member.param: The real part of the complex value.
The imaginary part of the complex value.
member.returns: The logarithm of the complex value as a tuple of 2 BigNumbers values.
member.exception: If real and imaginary are both 0.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Round(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,System.MidpointRounding)
member.remarks: This method should not need to be implemented because it's a static virtual method and the default implementation is what we want. However, static virtual methods are not yet supported by Rider so we need this here for now.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.RoundSigFigs(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.MidpointRounding)
member.summary: Round off a value to a certain number of significant figures.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Truncate(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.remarks: This method should not need to be implemented because it's a static virtual method and the default implementation is what we want. However, static virtual methods are not yet supported by Rider so we need this here for now.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Frac(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: Return the fractional part of the value. There are multiple ways to define the frac() function for negative numbers. (Refer to the Wikipedia link below.) The definition used in this implementation simply takes the digits to the right of the decimal point, with the sign matching the argument. e.g. Frac(12.345) => 0.345 Frac(-12.345) => -0.345 The following expression will be true for both positive and negative numbers: x == Truncate(x) + Frac(x)

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Floor(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.remarks: This method should not need to be implemented because it's a static virtual method and the default implementation is what we want. However, static virtual methods are not yet supported by Rider so we need this here for now.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Ceiling(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.remarks: This method should not need to be implemented because it's a static virtual method and the default implementation is what we want. However, static virtual methods are not yet supported by Rider so we need this here for now.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.RoundSigFigs(System.Numerics.BigInteger,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.MidpointRounding)
member.summary: Given a significand and exponent, and a maximum number of significant figures, determine the new significand and exponent.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.ShiftBy(System.Int32)
member.summary: Move the decimal point to the right by the specified number of places. This will effectively multiply the significand by 10 and decrement the exponent to maintain the same value, the specified number of times. NB: The value will probably not be canonical after calling this method, so it should only be used on temporary variables.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.ShiftToSigFigs(System.Nullable{System.Int32})
member.summary: Shift such that the significand has a certain number of significant digits. NB: The value will probably not be canonical after calling this method, so it should only be used on temporary variables.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.ShiftToExp(System.Int32)
member.summary: Shift such that the exponent has a certain value. NB: The value will probably not be canonical after calling this method, so it should only be used on temporary variables.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Align(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: Adjust the parts of one of the values so both have the same exponent. Two new objects will be returned.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.MakeCanonical(System.Numerics.BigInteger,System.Int32)
member.summary: Modify the provided significand and exponent as needed to find the canonical form. Static form of the method, for use in the constructor.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.MakeCanonical
member.summary: Make the value into its canonical form. Any trailing 0s on the significand are removed, and this information is transferred to the exponent. This method mutates the object; it doesn't return a new object like most of the other methods, because no information is lost.
member.returns: The instance, which is useful for method chaining.

member.summary: Divides two BigNumbers values together to compute their modulus or remainder.
member.returns: The modulus or remainder of a divided by b.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.ArithmeticGeometricMean(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: Compute the arithmetic-geometric mean of two values.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.op_ExclusiveOr(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: Exponentiation operator.
member.returns: The first operand raised to the power of the second.
member.exception: If the base is 0 and the exponent is negative or imaginary.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.ToString(System.String,System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary:
Format the BigNumbers as a string. Supported formats are the usual: D, E, F, G, N, P, and R.
Although "D" is normally only used by integral types, in this case both the significand and exponent will be formatted as integers. An secondary code "U" is provided, which follows the precision (if given). - If omitted, the exponent (if present) will be formatted with the usual E[-+]999 format. - If present, the exponent is formatted with "×10" instead of "E" and the exponent digits will be rendered as superscript. Also, a "+" sign is not used for positive exponents, and the exponent digits are not zero-padded. Example: "E7U" will format as per usual (E with 7 decimal digits), except using Unicode characters for the exponent part. Codes "R" and "D" will produce the same output. However, the Unicode flag is undefined with "R", because Parse() doesn't support superscript exponents.
member.exception: If the format specifier is invalid.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.ToString
member.remarks: Override of ValueType.ToString(). Needed for debugging and string interpolation.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Parse(System.String)
member.summary: More convenient version of Parse().

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.TryParse(System.String,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal@)
member.summary: More convenient version of TryParse().

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.PreformatFixed
member.summary: From a BigNumbers, extract two strings of digits that would appear if the number was written in fixed-point format (i.e. without an exponent). Sign is ignored.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.FormatFixedSigFigs(System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Format as fixed point, except in this case the precision is the number of significant figures, not the number of decimal places. Note, this is not technically formatting as significant figures, since trailing 0s following the decimal point are not retained, as per the usual format for "G".

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.FormatScientific(System.String,System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Format the value using scientific notation.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.FormatExponent(System.String,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Format the exponent part of scientific notation.
member.param: The original format code (e.g. E, e, G, or g). We need to know this to determine whether to use an upper- or lower-case 'E'.
Whether to use Unicode or standard format.
The minimum number of digits in the exponent (typically 3 for E and 2 for G). Relevant for standard (non-Unicode) format only.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.FormatRegex
member.remarks:
Pattern explanation:
○ Match if at the beginning of the string.
○ "format" capture group.
○ Match a character in the set [D-GNPRd-gnpr].
○ "precision" capture group.
○ Match a Unicode digit atomically any number of times.
○ "unicode" capture group.
○ Match a character in the set [Uu] atomically, optionally.
○ Match if at the end of the string or if before an ending newline.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Atan2(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: This two-argument variation of the Atan() method comes originally from FORTRAN. If x is non-negative, it will find the same result as Atan(y / x). If x is negative, the result will be offset by π. The purpose of the method is to produce a correct value for the polar angle when converting from cartesian coordinates to polar coordinates. It also avoids division by 0 exceptions.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Atan2Pi(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: Computes the arc-tangent for the quotient of two values and divides the result by pi.
member.exception: If x and y both equal 0.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.CartesianToPolar(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: Convert cartesian coordinates to polar coordinates.
member.returns: A tuple containing the radius (r) and angle (a).

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.PolarToCartesian(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: Convert polar coordinates to cartesian coordinates.
member.returns: A tuple containing the x and y coordinates.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.NormalizeAngle(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal@)
member.summary: Shift given angle to the equivalent angle in the interval [-π, π).
